Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Ethnographic Perspectives on the Mental Health of Female Youth in Court-Ordered Residential Treatment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Disruptive behavior disorders are relatively recent classifications in psychiatry and represent a trend to medicalize behavior. Alongside this development, American youth within the juvenile justice system have fallen under added psychiatric scrutiny and increasingly have been diagnosed with these disorders. Few scholars have addressed mental illness and juvenile detention and fewer have studied girls specifically, whose experiences may be unique. This study asks three critical questions about the process and experience of psychiatric diagnosis among female youth court-ordered to residential treatment in New York. First, what is the history of these diagnostic categories, and how might their history parallel developments in mental health interventions that target criminalized and poor youth of color? Second, how are these diagnoses used (or potentially challenged) by juvenile justice gatekeepers to identify and label youth from particular backgrounds as "problematic"? Third, how do youth, their families, and other members of the residential community understand, embrace and/or challenge these labels?

This study takes an interdisciplinary approach, drawing first on literature in psychological and medical anthropology and integrated, in turn, with work on pathology and criminality in psychology and sociology. Through participant observation, interviews with youth, their guardians, and treatment center staff, and archival research on case records, data will be collected to elucidate how psychiatric diagnoses are assigned, experienced and reformulated in this community.

Such data have practical implications for juvenile justice and public health. The importance of understanding how mental health and illness intersect with the juvenile justice system cannot be underestimated, particularly when this population is disproportionately minority and from the lowest socioeconomic brackets of society. Furthermore, as the number of female youth in detention rises, it is imperative that policy-makers understand the changing face of this population and consider the unique ways that female deviance is folded into mental illness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study examined the experiences of female youth in residential treatment who have been diagnosed with a variety of psychiatric disorders. In particular, the study sought to uncover the multiple ways that youth have been categorized—by the governmental agencies that refer them to the institution (juvenile justice, foster care, or special education), by the psychiatric diagnoses attached to their case records, and by the therapeutic interventions in which they engage—and to understand how youth are both shaped by those categories and reshape them in turn.

This study utilized a number of complementary ethnographic research methods during 11 months of fieldwork. Participant observation and systematic observation were conducted on the residential treatment center campus, in the homes of residents, and in Family Court in two boroughs of New York City. Eighteen semi-structured interviews were conducted on the campus; eight female juvenile justice residents (all female; ages 15-17) and ten staff members (nine female and one male) were interviewed about their experiences with juvenile justice and residential treatment, as well as about their perceptions of mental health. Finally, the study reviewed case records of the residents who were interviewed in order to triangulate data from a variety of sources.

The findings from this study suggest there is a complex interplay between the fairly strict principles structuring the institution and the creative work by residents and staff encountered in the minutiae of every day life. On the one hand, a number of different classifications had important implications for institutional functioning and shaped female youth in meaningful ways. For example, psychiatric diagnoses and perceptions of clinical need were related to a resident’s referral source. Youth referred by the juvenile justice system were significantly more likely to be diagnosed with a Disruptive Behavior Disorder whereas youth referred by the foster care system were significantly more likely to be diagnosed with a Mood Disorder; juvenile justice residents generally were perceived as having fewer clinical needs than residents from other referral sources. Classifications were also meaningful within the primary clinical intervention for residents, a peer-led group therapy known as Guided Group Interaction. Within this intervention, residents were responsible for labeling their problem behaviors in specific language that mirrors symptoms for behavioral disorders in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. On the other hand, residents worked to reshape the boundaries of the classifications imposed on them. They largely marginalized the salience of mental health problems in their lives and they steered Guided Group Interaction toward specific ends. Furthermore, they took up psychiatric diagnoses in creative and strategic ways; claiming to have Bipolar Disorder, even when one had not been diagnosed as such, became a strategic way to avoid taking responsibility for behavior. In turn, female residents transformed collective understanding about each other and about the contours of psychiatric disorder.

This study contributes to work on mental illness within anthropology and related fields and has a number of important implications for serving youth within residential treatment centers and the juvenile justice system.
